title: Lesson 18: Matrix Operations
lesson_title: Matrix operations: transpose and block matrices

cards.front: What is the transpose of a matrix \( A \)?
cards.back:
The matrix \( A^T \) obtained by interchanging rows and columns.

If \( A \) is \( m \times n \), then \( A^T \) is \( n \times m \).

\( (A^T)_{ij} = A_{ji} \)

\( (A^T)^T = A \)

Transposing twice returns the original matrix.

\( (A + B)^T = A^T + B^T \)

The transpose of a sum is the sum of transposes.

\( (AB)^T = B^T A^T \)

The transpose of a product reverses the order.

\( (cA)^T = cA^T \)

Scalars pass through the transpose.

A matrix partitioned into smaller matrices (blocks or submatrices).

Example:
\( \begin{bmatrix} A & B \\ C & D \end{bmatrix} \)

where \( A, B, C, D \) are matrices of compatible dimensions.

cards.front: How do you multiply block matrices?
cards.back:
Treat blocks like scalar entries, but preserve order (matrix multiplication isn't commutative).

\( \begin{bmatrix} A & B \\ C & D \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} E \\ F \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} AE + BF \\ CE + DF \end{bmatrix} \)

Blocks must have compatible dimensions.

cards.front: What is a block diagonal matrix?
cards.back:
A block matrix where all off-diagonal blocks are zero:

\( \begin{bmatrix} A_1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & A_2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & A_3 \end{bmatrix} \)

Each diagonal block can be analyzed independently.

cards.front: What is \( (A^{-1})^T \) if \( A \) is invertible?
cards.back:
\( (A^{-1})^T = (A^T)^{-1} \)

The transpose of the inverse equals the inverse of the transpose. Often written \( A^{-T} \).

cards.front: What is the determinant of a block diagonal matrix?
cards.back:
The product of the determinants of the diagonal blocks:

\( \det \begin{bmatrix} A & 0 \\ 0 & B \end{bmatrix} = \det(A) \cdot \det(B) \)
